docs.lead_paragraph: AS a contestant on TV's "Jeopardy," Bradley C. Plovan had all the answers. He knew the name of the composer buried next to Beethoven in Vienna ("Who was Schubert?"). He knew the title of the speech William Jennings Bryan delivered at the 1896 Democratic Convention ("What is the 'Cross of Gold' speech?"). He even knew the nickname of Irwin Handelman, a character on the sitcom "Family Ties" ("What is 'Skippy?' "). But when it came to deciding what to do with his $61,000 prize for his five consecutive victories on the show, Mr. Plovan, a 30-year-old Baltimore lawyer, did not have a clue.

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Legislature made a harried dash toward adjournment on Friday and early this morning, passing bills to enact a long-delayed budget and moving toward the approval of legislation that would deregulate hospitals and authorize a $1.75 billion environmental bond act. Eager to finish so members could return home and campaign for re-election, the Legislature started approving the $66 billion budget that Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders settled upon on Thursday. Most legislators got their first look at the lengthy budget bills after the agreement, which ended the longest delay in passing a state budget in the nation's history. [Page 24.]

headline.main: In Albany, a Dash To Complete Work As Vacation Nears

docs.lead_paragraph: At Bob Dole's urging, Republican Congressional leaders moved today to either enact welfare legislation or force President Clinton into a veto they could use against him in the election campaign. They announced plans to make two bills out of a measure that would give states more authority to control welfare and Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor, and would limit Federal spending on both. They noted that Mr. Clinton had denounced their proposals for Medicaid, which covers many people in nursing homes along with poor families, and said he was likely to veto any bill that included Medicaid.

headline.main: Republicans Shift Strategy in Bid to Avoid Welfare Bill Veto

docs.lead_paragraph: By holding the budget hostage for more than three months, Gov. George E. Pataki gambled that he could pressure legislative leaders into enacting major changes in several areas of state government. But in the end, he felt the pressure as much as the legislators did, and ultimately settled today on a budget deal that gave all sidessomething to walk away with.

headline.main: After Standoff, Both Sides Can Take Credit for Victories

docs.lead_paragraph: Ostentatiously unified, a group of Democratic Party officials today finished the first stage of drafting a party platform that reflects President Clinton's policies across a range of issues but tries to remain broad enough so that Democrats who disagree with the President on particular points will not be antagonized. Not one voice of dissent was raised in the two days that the party's Platform Drafting Committee met here.

headline.main: Democrats Drafting a Platform With a Corner for Dissent

docs.lead_paragraph: The stocks of managed care companies plummeted yesterday as the United Healthcare Corporation joined a parade of health insurers disclosing bad news to investors. The selloff in health care stocks contributed heavily to the sharp retreat in the overall stock market, which was also pulled down by a plunge in technology issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and state legislative leaders announced a tentative agreement late Wednesday night on revamping the state's $5 billion system of compensating injured workers, opening the way for final passage of the latest budget in state history. The deal also allowed the Legislature to extend for 36 hours a law that protects thousands of loft tenants in New York City, just as it was set to expire. Many tenants had feared that owners of loft buildings could have begun eviction proceedings if the law had lapsed for just one day. The Legislature is expected to eventually extend the law for at least two years.

docs.lead_paragraph: PESKY flying objects have been attacking random houses, cars, office buildings, plants -- and in at least one case, a woman's derriere. The attackers are tiny masses of spores that are forcibly ejected from a fungus that grows mainly on mulch and is called, aptly, the artillery or shotgun fungus.

headline.main: A Globby Fungus Is on the Attack

docs.lead_paragraph: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the largest life insurer in North America, agreed yesterday to pay a record $35.3 million in fines and reimburse customers across the country as a group of state regulators issued a sweeping, stinging rebuke to what it called widespread abuses by the company in the sale of life insurance. "Consumers put their confidence and their money into Prudential and the company's agents led them astray," New Jersey's Banking and Insurance Commissioner, Elizabeth Randall, said at a news conference in Trenton yesterday. "Prudential is responsible for any harm to its customers and therefore is responsible for correcting that harm."

headline.main: Prudential Agrees to Pay $35.3 Million In State Fines

docs.lead_paragraph: As a matter of pure politics, Republicans in Congress have handled the minimum wage as an exercise in snatching defeat from the jaws of defeat. Or at least snatching prolonged, painful defeat from the jaws of quick, change-the-subject defeat. Since March, Democrats have marveled at their good fortune as Republicans fought off holding a vote on raising the $4.25 per hour wage. Democrats thought they would win, sooner or later, because the public overwhelmingly supports an increase, but they never counted on dominating Congressional debate with the issue. Speaker Newt Gingrich saw that risk, and let the House vote in May, so the Republicans could reclaim the agenda.
